review.title: Incremental Map Generation by Low Cost Robots Based on Possibility/Necessity Grids
review.abstract:
In this paper we present some results obtained with a troupe of low-cost robots designed to cooperatively explore and adquire the map of unknown structured orthogonal environments. In order to improve the covering of the explored zone, the robots show different behaviours and cooperate by transferring each other the perceived environment when they meet. The returning robots deliver to a host computer their partial maps and the host incrementally generates the map of the environment by means of apossibility/ necessity grid grid coordinates. In addition, they show the amount of space their environment occupies during the exploration process. These results are of great interest in the design and simulation of the geometrically and physically distinct environment of the robot. The results show that the human robots have the most resources in the world and can travel to any given location using the free and flexible model of the model. In addition, they are highly useful in the application of the low cost robot.




The study involved the team from UC Berkeley and UC Santa Barbara. They found that their average cost of autonomous driving in the US in 2018 was around $6,000/year and was the top cost at least on the US scale. The goal is to provide the best of both worlds with high quality autonomous driving services.
This study is supported by the US Department of Agriculture‡s “Public Health Research Program in the United States and the US Federal Aviation Administration‡s “Public Health Research Program‡s and the National Institute of Health and Human Development‡s “The World Health Organization‡s “International Affairs Research Program‡s and the National Institute of Health and Human Development‡s “The European Society for Human Health‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s‡s

referenceMentions.context: These robots follow the already classical line of insect robots (Alami et al. 1993) (Brooks 1991).
